Once again, I urge Democratic leadership to consider a real solution to ending the shutdown, whether it be one of my proposals or that of another Member of Congress, that will have a fair chance at Senate consideration and becoming law.

My amendment not only gets us closer to reopening our government, but also protects our national security, addresses vulnerable immigrant communities who seek legal status, and helps those who are rebuilding after Hurricane Michael.
I am exceedingly disappointed Democratic leadership has yet again rejected an amendment which would garner bipartisan support and will not have the opportunity to be debated on the House floor.
This shutdown is unnecessary and is hurting the thousands of federal employees furloughed and the countless American families who depend on federal programs.

At Rules Committee tonight, I presented a commonsense solution to end this shutdown. The amendment I proposed includes funding for border security, provides permanent relief for #DREAMers + #TPS recipients, + delivers critical dollars to communities impacted by natural disasters.

La decisión de hoy es un paso firme en la dirección correcta, y felicito al presidente Trump y al secretario Pompeo por su audaz liderazgo.
Sin embargo, la decisión de las sucesivas administraciones de ejercer la autoridad de suspensión del estatuto puede haberles dado confianza en un falso sentido de impunidad.

Desde 1996, las empresas que decidieron explotar estas propiedades confiscadas con el régimen han estado al tanto de que las demandas para proteger los derechos de los propietarios estadounidenses son inevitables.

Aquellos cuyas posesiones fueron robadas por el régimen de Castro han sufrido la pérdida durante décadas, mientras que entidades sin escrúpulos se asocian con el régimen para sacar provecho de ese robo.

El movimiento sin precedentes de la administración Trump para acortar la duración de la autoridad de suspensión legal del Título III debe servir como una señal para aquellos que continúan violando la ley de los Estados Unidos mediante el tráfico de propiedades confiscadas.

Let’s come together to help disaster-impacted communities, reopen the government, and fix our broken immigration system, including securing our border and providing a solution to DREAMers and TPS beneficiaries.
Bipartisanship is the solution to fund programs that support veterans, house vulnerable populations, and protect our national security.

This bill has zero chance of either Senate consideration or becoming law, + everyone knows it. We also cannot leave the thousands of fed employees in limbo w/o a paycheck+financial certainty. I continue to call on Dem leadership to participate in good faith negotiations.

Today Dem leadership orchestrated another political stunt, this time putting critical supplemental disaster funding at risk. Hurricane Michael devastated parts of the Sunshine State, and these communities are desperately awaiting federal support to continue rebuilding.

I look forward to continuing to work with the administration to ensure that those who profit from trafficking in stolen property are held accountable, and that the victims receive the justice which is long overdue.

However, the decision by successive administrations to exercise the statute’s suspension authority may have lulled some into a false sense of impunity. Today’s decision is a firm step in the right direction, and I commend President Trump and Sec. Pompeo for their bold leadership.
Since 1996, businesses who decided to exploit these confiscated properties with the regime have been on notice that lawsuits to protect the rights of American property holders are inevitable.
Those whose properties were stolen by the Castro regime have endured the loss for decades, while unscrupulous entities partner with the regime to profit from that theft.

The Trump administration’s unprecedented move to shorten the duration of Title III’s statutory suspension authority should serve as a signal to those who continue to break U.S. law by trafficking in confiscated properties.

Mobility vouchers, which give families w small children the ability to move to neighborhoods with greater economic opportunities, is completely zeroed out in today’s bill. The House bill funded this program at $50M, giving countless families a better chance at the American dream.
That missing $18M would result in 1,700 people losing their housing. It is vital to #SoFla that this program receive the necessary funding to ensure no individual is left behind.
HOPWA is a housing program that helps those living with HIV/AIDS, a vulnerable community I’m proud to support. We funded it at $393M, and the Senate dropped it to $375M.

Disabled vouchers, a major priority of mine, drops ↓ from $390M in House bill to $154M in this bill, + includes *no new vouchers*. How many needy people could be helped by that missing $236M, including our nations veterans, and the tens of thousands of new vouchers we provided?

Funding for ports, a first for the #transportation bill, was included in our House bill. This version completely zeroes out that account. That funding is critical for Florida and other parts of the country that have seaports, which are huge economic drivers for the country.
This funding goes directly to states, thereby avoiding bureaucracy and red tape.

Highway funding, which is critical for the repair of our roadways and bridges, is lowered from $3.8B in our bill, to $2.4B in the Senate bill. That $1.4B is huge, especially to communities that are still rebuilding from natural disasters.

Whether in D.C. or in Florida, he has spent countless hours presenting the town’s case for a unique ZIP Code and I am grateful for his support. Together, I am confident that we will get this bill signed into law.
I thank Mayor Cid for his continued efforts and engagement on this critical issue. He has been a great partner to work with and continues to be Miami Lakes’ strongest advocate.

I will continue to work with my House and Senate colleagues to get this bill to the President’s desk and am hopeful that Mayor Cid and the town will be granted the unique ZIP Code they so desperately need.
That is why I will not relent until Miami Lakes and its residents are granted the relief they need, and why I am introducing similar legislation again this Congress.

The impact a unique ZIP Code would have on Miami Lakes residents cannot be understated. From higher insurance rates to election and census confusion to branding and economic development – lack of a unique ZIP Code has been a costly and burdensome issue for my constituents.
Bills I’ve introduced in previous Congresses have passed the House but have not even been considered by the Senate.

Just tonight, I presented four amendments that would address the legal status of DREAMers and TPS beneficiaries, yet Speaker Pelosi was not willing to consider even one of them.

We must find a solution to the more than 11 million undocumented individuals who are living in the shadows, + that solution must be reasonable and humane. Lastly, a bipartisan solution to immigration reform must bolster the economy + respect the rule of law of this great nation.

We must modernize our visa system so that American business owners have the power to lawfully hire employees for job vacancies that are hard to fill. Modernizing our visa system also allows us to better track who is traveling through our borders.
The US has the responsibility to determine who and what goes through its borders. There are numerous issues that are problematic and remain unsolved.
Speaker Pelosi: let’s put aside the political games, reopen the government, secure our border, and give permanent, legal status to DREAMers and TPS beneficiaries.

Every day that passes, this shutdown becomes more damaging, hurting hundreds of thousands of federal workers, as well as Americans across the country that rely on government programs affected by the lapse in funding.
Sadly, this is not the first time the rhetoric of Democratic leadership does not align with their actions.

Just last year, Speaker Pelosi spent eight hours on the House floor, demanding a vote on a DREAMer bill. Yet, here I am, giving her not one, not two, not three, but FOUR opportunities to help DREAMers, and she is handily rejecting them all.

Democratic leadership is so focused on political gimmickry, they refused to even allow consideration of amendments that would reopen the government and resolve an issue they claim is one of their top priorities.
